reviewText: I'm finally getting around with my review for Season Five. The series continues to be goodAlso this season gives a new intro to each episode. I would see it while the series was in syndication and it was refreshing to see that. The new intro starting with season five uses a person along with the graphics.All the episodes are good but space won't allow me to describe each episode. So I'm picking two that stand out,Tribunal: Definitely the best one for season five. It opens at the Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp. The date is March 1944 and the camp inmates are assembling for morning roll call. Camp commander, SS Lieutenant Karl Rademacher, has his morning ritual of shooting an inmate execution style. On this morning he picks Leon Zgierski but instead shoots his wife while in the presence of Leon and his young daughter Hannah. An mysterious man (Nicholas Prentice AKA time traveler and will appear in future episodes) makes a note in a digital notebook. Rademacher sees him and orders guards after Prentice. Prentice barely escapes but not before grabbing Rademacher's uniform jacket. A half a century passes. Leon is still alive.(A Nazi guard ordered him sent to a labor camp but takes away his daughter, presumably to the gas chambers) Leon has a son from a second marriage named Aaron (named after an inmate Leon met at Auschwitz who was seen being led away by a Nazi guard). Aaron is a lawyer who devotes time to finding Rademacher who he believes is living in America under the name Robert Greene. However Aaron has no evidence. Aaron later gets a visit from Prentice who says he has an interest in bringing Robert Greene to justice. Prentice makes several visits to Aaron bringing good evidence that helps build a case against Greene. Aaron however wants to know more about Prentice so he follows him to his hotel. Aaron goes to Prentice's room and finds the door ajar. He walks in while Prentice is in the shower. Aaron picks up an antique watch which is the time travel device Prentice uses and activates it sending him to the 1944 Auschwich. While there Aaron sees the younger Rademacher and the younger Leon Zgierski and Hannah and they talk. In time Prentice comes out of the shower and sees the watch on the floor. He figures Aaron was in the room so he goes back to 1944 Auschwitz in a Nazi uniform to bring Aaron back. Aaron was in the barracks with other inmates and was seen by the younger Leon being led away. They return to the present. By now Aaron is freaking out and Prentice is forced to reveal who he really is and where he is from (the future where time travel is possible). Prentice would later tell Aaron that Greene killed members of his family. At a later time Prentice is forced to tell Aaron that with evidence closing on him, Greene would buy a ticket out of the country to never be heard from again. this upsets Aaron so he goes to Greene's house to kill him. Prentice follows Aaron with more news: Prentice is Aaron's great grandson and if something happens to him, Prentice will cease to exist. Aaron doesn't kill Greene. Instead Aaron and Prentice in Nazi uniforms take Robert Greene, in inmate clothing, to 1944 Auschwitz. Aaron and Prentice take Greene as a belligerent prisoner to the younger Rademacher. It is at this point where Robert Greene-to Aaron's satisfaction-confesses that he is Karl Rademacher. The younger Rademacher thinking he's just another prisoner shoots him point blank. After that Aaron sees the younger Leon and rushes to him. Aaron orders the younger Leon to the labor camp (Keeping him alive) but drags Hannah away from him. Hannah is taken to the future. The next scene is Hannah being taken to the older Leon. Leon sees her and thinks old age is causing him to see things. He is shown the camp number tattoed to her arm. The reunion is emotional. Prentice walks away and transports to another time which will be seen in a future episode. The episode ends with a note from writer Sam Egan: "Dedicated to my father who survived Auschwitz...and to his wife and daughter who did not".The other powerful episode because some will give their all to save the lives of others.Summit: In a future time Earth and the planet Dregocia (residents called Dregs) are at war. Both sides agree to meet on a barren planet to talk peace. Members of the earth delegation are on the planet when the shuttle carrying the Dregocian delagation leaves it's mother ship. Something goes wrong with the Dregocian shuttle and sabatoge is blamed. The two mother ships fire on one another destroying them both. The Dreg shuttle crashes sending shock waves causing damage to the structure. People are killed to include the earth ambassador and there are system failures. At this point forces from Earth and Dregocia are launched and in three hours both sides will reach the point where missles can be launched. Billoins on both sides can be killed. With the Earth ambassador killed an underling Kate Woods is in charge. They have no way to contact earth to order a standdown because the transmitter was destroyed. There are survivors from the Dregocian shuttle-Ambassador Prosser and an aid. Both sides do meet. After much contention and a test by the Dregs to prove sincerity the two sides do work together. An agreement is reached and a standdown order gets sent out-just barely. However there was one member of the Earth coalition that was against the negotiations and kills the Dregocian aid. More shots are fired and Ambassador Prosser is killed. Transmissions do come through. One from a Earth high official, the other from an Dregocian admiral. The Dregocoian admiral will only talk to Ambassador Prosser. The admiral learns all from the Dregocian delegation was killed and believes foul play and starts to resume the attack on Earth. Here we see the selfless acts. Acting Ambassador Kate Woods offers her life. At first that is unacceptable but the other members of the Earth delegation offer their lives as well. That is acceptable. Kate Woods does get a message to her young son. One by one each member takes their life as a peace offering. Kate Woods is the last to die. The final scene is after Kate dies, her young son back on Earth awakes from his sleep and calls for his mom.Once again they got it right with the packaging. The discs are held in their own compartment. There were no problems with the discs when played. Also Amazon did it's usual good job. I used the SuperSaver shipping and had the item in a matter of days. Good job.
summary: Great Series/Good Episodes/And Right With The Packaging

reviewText: Five years after MGM released Season 1 in the U.S., the rest of the series is being issued in Canada. It's great to have these episodes, several of which I missed when they were originally broadcast.Unfortunately, these are the edited versions. The series was originally shown on Showtime, and included some brief nudity and an occasional four-letter expletive. Edited versions were then prepared for syndication, with the nudity and strong language edited out, and commercial breaks inserted.While the Season Two set included the originals, with the exception of one episode, Seasons Three, Four and Five have only the edited versions. In many cases, this doesn't change things too much, but there are some episodes that are less effective.The real disappointment is the video quality. It's tolerable, but far below the standard for DVD. I didn't realize just how bad it is until I went back and looked at some of the MGM discs. Seasons 2 and 3 were OK, but Season 4 shows a real drop in fidelity, which continues with Season 5.I'd give the series four stars for the quality of the stories and the production, but it's a shame that they couldn't produce a DVD package that's up to modern standards. This is better than having a set of old VHS tapes recorded from the commercial broadcast.  If MGM ever issues, the rest of the series with the same quality as its Season 1 and themed releases, I will definitely buy the series again.Since that may never happen --- it's been over five years since the MGM Season 1 --- I'll have to make do with these sets.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I cannot abide by any of the currently available 'New Outer Limits' box sets, collections, etc., with the exception of the Season One MGM box.The syndicated episodes were all edited to make room for commercials as well as to censor certain erotic scenes which wereincluded in the original SHOWTIME airings. 'LITHIA' is the best example of an episode containing erotic scenes both heterosexualas well as explicit lesbianism. Until these uncensored & unedited episodes are available I'm not interested.
summary: Will the real Outer Limits please stand up?
Title: N/A

reviewText: I agree with other reviewers of these Complete Season Outer Limits box sets that this has to be the worst designed packaging I have ever seen for holding DVDs. I rate the episodes 4-stars. I would have rated the episodes 5-stars - except Canadian Home Video censored them to remove the occasional female bare breast that was shown in the MGM releases. Actually, the boxes all these Canadian Home Video DVDs came in rates 0-stars, so I am giving this product an overall rating of 3-stars.The Complete 2nd Season of Outer Limits put out by Canadian Home Video is uncensored, but seasons 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 put out by Canadian Home Video were all censored to remove rough language & every brief trace of nudity. Anyone who wants to see at least some of the uncensored episodes in these seasons must buy the various "theme" collections put out by MGM. All of the MGM "theme" releases are uncensored.Now more on the awful Canadian boxes. To keep from scratching the Outer Limits DVDs trying to remove them from their boxes, or while putting them back in, I found the best way is to put all the DVDs into an empty "spindle" box that had originally held blank CDs or DVDs.I bought all 6 of the Canadian Home Video sets (Seasons two thru seven), dumped the boxes, & put all the Outer Limits DVDs (in order) into an empty spindle box that I had originally bought from Staples & that had held 40 blank DVD+RW discs. Now I can easily lift out any year & episode I want to watch, without having to fight the stupid little plastic clips holding each DVD in its Canadian box. The season number, disk number, & episode name are clearly shown on top of each DVD, so it is easy to find the one I want. Problem solved.
Title: N/A
